body:
the ci docker has caffe installed, also gpu is enabled if you want to use.
see.

https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/tests/ci_build/Dockerfile.caffe_gpu

i suggest to download a model, feed in an image, and compared the results
to make sure that the difference is small

the current test script is here:
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/tools/caffe_converter/test_converter.py

On Tue, Jun 13, 2017 at 11:29 AM, Arik Poznanski <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> I'm not sure how to go about that..
> Is running the tool enough? should I add assertion to make sure the per
> layer difference is low?
> Also, the tool depends on caffe being setup properly (such that 'import
> caffe' works), can this be an issue for integration tests?
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you commented.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/6680#issuecomment-308206911>, or mute
> the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAZv4aVKrxtVDxXCl_g8eRKQ3KWXSg28ks5sDtUKgaJpZM4N4Atd>
> .
>

I think we have then to do the "detection" flow eventually in which we dynamically turn it off and issue a warning message. Though I rather would submit this flow with a separate PR soon to keep us going here and not complicate things further. 
So I will make the default not to use lapack (but for a short period). The downside of this is that I then have to disable also all the tests for these operators in test_operator.py, so we won't run automatic regressions (unless we would modify Jenkins setup). I think this is bad, but tolerable for a short time.
Ok with that approach Eric?

Currently **test_converter.py** downloads the models and dataset and check the models performance,
while **compare_layers.py** downloads the models and a test image and check the models weights and outputs.

Do you think the **test_converter.py** script should cover both checks? in which case I need to merge them to a single file.

Or should I leave **compare_layers.py** as a standalone script, add the relevant assertions, possibly rename it to **test_compare_layers.py**, and add it to the list of CI tests?

i prefer to add the test codes into test_converter.py. but i'm ok with the
second option as well

@chunyang-wen Thanks! Your example works.
The one I am having trouble with loading is the model I converted from caffe model zoo. The model has a mean.binaryproto which can be converted through mxnet/tool/caffe_converter/convert_mean.py and I have problem loading the converted file. Do you think it is the version?

Is it possible that the performance gap comes from the difference of basic layers?

The neural net visualized in MXnet is given as follows.
[Deeplab.pdf](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/files/1072624/Deeplab.pdf)

.json file for mxnet:
[deeplab.txt](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/files/1076200/deeplab.txt)

In caffe, the net visualization is given as follows.
[resnet-101_dl.pdf](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/files/1072639/resnet-101_dl.pdf)

.prototxt file for caffe:
[deeplab_caffe.txt](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/files/1076210/deeplab_caffe.txt)

I have no problem training with your data. 
There seems to be a problem with your code, 
```
label_pad_width = -1
```
will estimate the maximum label width in record file, however, we have train.rec and val.rec, so the estimated widths might differ, causing the data shape inconsistent between training/validation, which will trigger the crash.
@dtmoodie

Could you clarify the meaning of label_pad_width, I was under the impression that it pads the images such that all images are of label_pad_width size.  Thus the input data and labels are of a consistent size within a batch.
I thought setting this to -1 was automatically determining the value at runtime.
I did this because the mapillary dataset has different size images, and it may be that the smaller dataset that I uploaded has a consistent size.
Cool

1. since each image has different number of objects, the label widths are different, this is fine within the record and list file.
2. During training, the data shape as well as label shape must be consistent across the training, thus the label_pad_width is used to pad every label to maximum width, use -1 here is still good because it will estimate the max width, for example, 200
3. However, the automatic estimation won't work for multiple record files, i.e. train.rec won't know how much to pad in val.rec, thus you have to set the label_pad_width manually. I know it is awkward, but synchronize the width between train_iterator and val_iterator will force them to reload again, which is not a good option neither. 

There will be a update on the data loading module for object detection tasks, so please bare with the current API for now.

I've refactored **test_converter.py** script to run both performance test and layer-by-layer comparison test for known models. The layer comparison login remains in a standalone **compare_layers.py** script, to avoid clouding the test_converter script, and to allow users to run the layer by layer comparison on their private models.

I've added assertion of mean difference allowed (1e-4) and max difference allowed (1e-2), based on actual numbers I got when running on CPU. Unfortunately, I can't run the test on GPU, so I hope it passes the integration test, and if not, we might need to update the threshold for the GPU. Hopefully, there won't be any significant difference..
Ah this makes more sense now. So width is not a pixel value but rather the number of objects?

@vk99 

I have made some changes in our R APIs, which allow users to set the input/output names in the network. A MF demo might be like below, where you need to define your own iterator. Please let me know your opinion, we can adjust according to users' comments.

```r
library(mxnet)
DF <- read.table("~/Downloads/ml-100k/u.data", header = F, sep = "\t")
names(DF) <- c("user", "item", "score", "time")
max_user <- max(DF$user)
max_item <- max(DF$item)
DF_mat_x <- data.matrix(t(DF[, 1:2]))
DF_y <- DF[, 3]
k <- 64
user <- mx.symbol.Variable("user")
item <- mx.symbol.Variable("item")
score <- mx.symbol.Variable("label")
user1 <-mx.symbol.Embedding(data = mx.symbol.BlockGrad(user), input_dim = max_user,
                            output_dim = k, name = "user1")
item1 <- mx.symbol.Embedding(data = mx.symbol.BlockGrad(item), input_dim = max_item,
                             output_dim = k, name = "item1")
pred <- user1 * item1
pred1 <- mx.symbol.sum_axis(pred, axis = 1, name = "pred1")
pred2 <- mx.symbol.Flatten(pred1, name = "pred2")
pred3 <- mx.symbol.LinearRegressionOutput(data = pred2, label = score, name = "pred3")
devices <- mx.cpu()
mx.set.seed(123)

CustomIter <- setRefClass("CustomIter", fields = c("iter1", "iter2"),
  contains = "Rcpp_MXArrayDataIter",
  methods = list(
    initialize = function(iter1, iter2) {
      .self$iter1 <- iter1
      .self$iter2 <- iter2
      .self
    },
    value = function() {
      user <- .self$iter1$value()$data
      item <- .self$iter2$value()$data
      label <- .self$iter1$value()$label
      list(user = user,
           item = item,
           label = label)
    },
    iter.next = function() {
      .self$iter1$iter.next()
      .self$iter2$iter.next()
    },
    reset = function() {
      .self$iter1$reset()
      .self$iter2$reset()
    },
    num.pad = function() {
      .self$iter1$num.pad()
    },
    finalize = function() {
      .self$iter1$finalize()
      .self$iter2$finalize()
    }
  )
)

user_iter = mx.io.arrayiter(data = DF[, 1], label = DF[, 3], batch.size = k)

item_iter = mx.io.arrayiter(data = DF[, 2], label = DF[, 3], batch.size = k)

train_iter <- CustomIter$new(user_iter, item_iter)

model <- mx.model.FeedForward.create(pred3, X = train_iter, ctx = devices,
                                     num.round = 10, initializer = mx.init.uniform(0.07),
                                     learning.rate = 0.07, eval.metric = mx.metric.rmse,
                                     momentum = 0.9, epoch.end.callback = mx.callback.log.train.metric(1),
                                     input.names = c("user", "item"), output.names = "label")
```

```
Start training with 1 devices
[1] Train-rmse=2.99220452429364
[2] Train-rmse=1.26099870759204
[3] Train-rmse=1.01667805282069
[4] Train-rmse=0.96222279260538
[5] Train-rmse=0.932117553011119
[6] Train-rmse=0.906196865509909
[7] Train-rmse=0.880440017092613
[8] Train-rmse=0.853122589011389
[9] Train-rmse=0.823560565300815
[10] Train-rmse=0.792171204878059
```

A Khatri-Rao product is a great addition! My main problem is the misleading name of the function: what is the rational behind using the transposed matrices?

If it returns the transpose of the Khatri-Rao product then it is **not** a khatri-rao product - which is a **column-wise** Kronecker product. This is potentially very confusing the end user.

It should either return the actual Khatri-Rao product or be renamed (e.g. row_wise_kronecker).
As a side note an elegant way to do the tests would be to use the Kronecker product and compare with the appropriate bit.

I think this can be done in a callback function.

In `function(iteration, nbatch, env, verbose)`, the `env` is an environment, where you can store your results.
I think this can be solved by #6673 , where you can define your own iterator and put into the training process.
yes
@nikrao are you using the lastest cuda 8? if not try upgrad cuda. It may solve the problem i guess.


Hi there,
Did you figure this out? I am getting the same issue. Thanks!
but `deconv1_1` do not change the shape when ```kernel=(3,3)``` and ```pad=(1,1)```
I just recompiled and still cannot make the mx.nd.concat or mx.nd.Concat work. Did I miss something obvious? Thanks!
@tornadomeet Yes, and that's exactly what I want, to make the input and output shape the same.
can you please provide the full stack trace to help further locate the problems ?

so your segmentation class number is ```32```?   
try change `deconv1_1` to 
```python
network['deconv1_1'] = mx.symbol.Activation(mx.symbol.Convolution(data = network['deconv1_2'], 
    kernel = (3, 3), num_filter = 32, pad = (1, 1), workspace = workspace), act_type = 'relu', name = 'deconv1_1')
```

@chunyang-wen 
```
mxnet::cpp::NDArray::GetShape (this=0x7fffffffdd90) at /mxnet/cpp-package/include/mxnet-cpp/ndarray.hpp:315
#1  0x000000000041076b in main (argc=1, argv=0x7fffffffe088) at test.cc:48
(gdb) bt full
#0  mxnet::cpp::NDArray::GetShape (this=0x7fffffffdd90) at /mxnet/cpp-package/include/mxnet-cpp/ndarray.hpp:315
        out_pdata = 0x7fffffffdd10
        out_dim = 0
        ret = std::vector of length 0, capacity 0
#1  0x000000000041076b in main (argc=1, argv=0x7fffffffe088) at test.cc:48
```

GetData() has the similar problem.
your label shape should be ```(batchsize, cls_num, 450, 794)```, and the num_filer of `deconv1_1` should be `cls_num`.
I use synthetic data just for a test. Class number is 31, and I leave one as ignore label.

```cpp
 ret = std::vector of length 0, capacity 0
```

It seems that `LoadToMap` loads the dict back, but there is no data in the value of ['mean_image']. I think you can try to check other contents. And make sure the converter does what you want.
I encounter the same problem, will MxNet  add a more efficient group convolutions implementation ?
thanks, @undertherain  is right, delete /usr/local/lib/python2.7/mxnet_*** , then install again.

is there any update for this issue? @piiswrong, @sbodenstein 
and there is a question may be not related to mxnet.
I've built the deep speech2 architecture in keras, tensorflow, and mxnet, but either of them achieves a good performance. The average loss computed from wrap-ctc stop in around 40 for the best.
The architecture is believed to be right. So how can I optimize the neural network to get the performance in  papers?

Many thanks

can you send the file "mean.nd" to me?

Currently I have no idea what happens. Under certain conditions, mxnet will call `CreateMeanImg` which will generate `mean_image`  for you.  But I did not find any clues for your problem.

You can send the file(`mean.nd`) to my gmail if it is ok for you. I will try to print logs in debug mode.

By the way: is running environment of python and cpp the same?
Like folder structure. location when running the program. etc.
[here](https://github.com/KeyKy/mobilenet-mxnet) has a mobilenet converted from caffe.

I thought num_hidden = 2 meant two nodes of one layer, and that these nodes could be connected to a one unit output without adding one more layer. This is obviously not the case. It can be solved by adding an extra layer with num_hidden = 1.
@flice  Do you have solved this problem? I also have this issue!
Thank you.
Update to R v.3.3 or 3.4!

I think that the BatchNorm layer with epslion is the main reason for that. If the epslion is lower than 1e-5(cudnn can not process the value lower than 1e-5), the caffe-to-mxnet convertion will lose accuracy.
I attached the link to download the model files I use. Thanks!!

I tested with cuDNN 6 when using JetPack 3.1 on TX2. Profiling of resnet_fp16.py shows that true FP16 cuda kernels are called (*_hcudnn_*) and no more *_fp16_* calls. Following findings have been made while profiling resnet_fp16.py with number layers = 18 and with batch size 8:
- FP16 convolutional kernels are 1.3-1.8x faster compared to FP32
- FP16 batch normalization kernels are 1.2-1.4x faster compared to FP32
- FP16 activation (RELU) kernels are also 1.2-1.4x faster compared to FP32
- overall cost of casting FP32 to FP16 is only 2% of the total run-time
Is that to be expected?
Profiler output is here: https://drive.google.com/open?id=0Bwb8o6lldJgBSUh0U2NEZXVvRW8
Overall, I observe 1.5x speed-up due to FP16 for batch size of 8 and input image resolution of 640x480, and increasing batch results into the similar speed-ups of 1.5x.
I have a few questions:
- reducing batch size to 4 and 1 shows much smaller gains of 1.2x and 1.1x due to FP16, respectively. Is that to be expected? Presumably this is due to the overhead of copying the data to/from GPU.
- keeping batch size = 8, but reducing by 2x the number of filters per layer shows a speed-up FP16 vs. FP32 of only 1.3x. Why is that?
-  reducing input image resolution to 0.7*original resolution does not affect significantly the gains due to FP16 for different batch sizes, compared to using original resolution
- when profiling my custom FP16 ResNet-18 that has dilated convolutions, I see pseudo-FP16 calls *_fp16_* for the dilated convolutions, and thus no speed-up over the corresponding FP32 kernels. Do you know if there is a timeline of supporting dilated convolutions?
- FP16 deconvolutional kernels cudnn::detail::dgrad2d_alg1_1_half<__half...> perform 10-15% worse compared to the corresponding FP32 deconvolutional kernels. Why?
Thanks a lot for your help !

Also, I just realized that it might be the same type of check that needs to be performed in order to fix #5296. When running on multiple devices, I guess the kvstore$push returns a list rather than MXNDArray.

@yzou2 If you have epslion less than or equal to 1e-5, you need to turn the cudnn off for this layer. You also need to comment out the 'eps_correction'(Ln149,Ln152) in the 'convert_model.py' file because the correction may cause accuracy loss when epslion < 1e-5 in a very deep network. After do that, my resnet101-fcn like model get all the same result as Caffe.
Set the mod.bind for_training=True of mxnet to get the same result as "use_global_stats: true" of Caffe.

Could you precise which version you installed and how? I just reinstalled the most recent version (on Ubuntu 16.04) and both `mx.nd.sqrt`  and rmsprop optimizer worked fine. 

@sagaragrawal13 is the issue with rmsprop appearing when running on multiple GPUs? There's currently an issue for all optimizers but SGD when training on multiple devices (#5296), but single CPU or GPU should be ok.

Sth I used before. FYI.
```python
class Debug(mx.operator.CustomOp):
    def forward(self, is_train, req, in_data, out_data, aux):
        f = open('s.txt','w')
        value = in_data[0].asnumpy()
        for i in range(value.size):
            f.write('%1.6f\n'%(value.flat[i]))
        f.close()
        #x = in_data[0].asnumpy()
        #for i in range(144):
        #    print(x[i])
        self.assign(out_data[0],req[0], in_data[0])

    def backward(self, req, out_grad, in_data, out_data, in_grad, aux):
        self.assign(in_grad[0],req[0], out_grad[0])
```
